Summary I am a board certified Developmental-Behavioral Pediatrician (DBP). My clinical interests include developmental delay, intellectual and learning disabilities, ADHD, autism, Asperger’s, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive, tic disorders, and psychopharmacology. My career experience straddles the subspecialty DBP and primary care worlds. A passion for teaching and interdisciplinary collaboration has prompted my involvement in numerous divide-bridging efforts - including programs to combine DBP with primary care, integrate inpatient & outpatient medicine, connect tertiary & primary care, and promote teamwork between pediatricians, psychologists, nurse practitioners, and other community partners.  
 
I have recently taken up a position as Clinical Assistant Professor in Developmental-Behavioral Pediatrics at Stanford University / Lucile Packard Children's Hospital. In this new post I hope to use my unique experience to develop programs supporting DB assessment and care across the Packard Children's Health Alliance (PCHA) primary care network.

Summary Dr. Robinson is clinical psychologist, published author, and an Instructor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University Medical Center. She completed a Post-Doctoral Research Fellowship at Stanford University. Currently, she is Principal Investigator of an NIMH funded K23 award for a randomized controlled trail comparing Cognitive Behavioral Therapy Guided Self-Help to Integrative Response Therapy for the treatment of Binge Eating Disorder. She is also trained and certified in multiple treatment modalities and provides supervision to therapists.  
 
Specialties include: eating disorders, overweight and obesity, bariatric surgery, cognitive behavioral therapy, interpersonal psychotherapy, dialectical behavior therapy, guided self-help approaches, family based therapy, cognitive remediation therapy for anorexia nervosa, compulsive exercise, disordered eating among athletes, interpersonal concerns, affect dysregulation. Summary I am a passionate physician-scientist focused on improving child health by promoting the safe and efficacious use of medications in children. My training and experiences form a strong foundation that allow me to actively pursue this objective. Following my medical school and pediatric residency training, I developed an in-depth 5-year post-doctoral clinical research experience at UCSF combining training in Clinical Pharmacology, Pharmacometrics, and General Pediatrics. This unique training platform provided the expertise I would need to coalesce my interests in therapeutic research with the clinical care of infants and children, and it launched my academic career in the field of pediatric clinical pharmacology and therapeutics. I am currently a faculty-member at Stanford University with an NIH-funded research program focused in pediatric therapeutics. Summary 10+ years of research experience in behavioral medicine with a focus on cardiovascular disease and other chronic conditions. I am passionate about developing and implementing efficacious self-management interventions in heart failure and related chronic conditions. I am currently developing self-management interventions that target couples. I am leading the evaluation of the mental health impact of the VA patient centered medical home for primary care (PACT).
